I saw her concert recently which was absolutely incredible and unforgettable. She and the dancers and acrobats which she invited gave a superb performance. The choreography, lighting, glow sticks and the stage design were marvelous. It was beyond my expectation. Yesterday I assigned four hours for practicing her songs on my piccolo, flute, oboe, cor anglais (english horn), clarinet, E-flat clarinet, bass clarinet, bassoon and contrabassoon. I practised with my friends who play triangle, tambourine, castanets, gongs, sleigh bells (jingle bells), cymbals (hi-hat, clash and ride), snare drum and bass drum, all of which have indefinite pitch. Oboe, cor anglais and bassoon are double-reed instruments whereas clarinet and saxophone are single-reed instruments. Flute is a reedless instrument.

replies.msg: I saw her live twice at Yokohama Arena which was absolutely incredible and unforgettable. The first time i saw her concert we were late. i remember i said "look at the time. The concert will have started." It was quarter past eight. The concert would've started by then. At the end of the last encore she bowed onstage soaking up the applause. She met with a thunderous ovation. It was a worthwhile concert that was compelling enough to see again. The singer and the dancers and acrobats who were invited to perform alongside her gave a magnificent performance. The choreography, stage and lighting design and the glow sticks were superb and.surpassed our expectations. The singer is very career-oriented. My brother whos also very career-minded is planning on having her endorse his company's products but he'll have to make it financially worthwhile for her. She has a worthwhile job and career because I consider music performing to be a worthwhile career. Yesterday I assigned five hours for practising her songs on my saxophone, piccolo, flute, onoe, cor anglais (english horn), clarinet, E-flat clarinet, bass clarinet, bassoon and contrabassoon. I practised with my friends who played glockenspiel, xylophone, vibraphone, marimba, timpani (kettle-drum), chimes and celesta, all of which have definite pitch. Saxophone, cor anglais and clarinet are transposing instruments. Saxophone, clarinet and bass clarinet are single reed instruments while one, cor anglais, bassoon and contrabassoon are double reed instruments. Flute is a reedless instrument. My friend Charles is a trumpeter. He explained to us regarding a piece by Haydn "this passage should be played beautifully rather than rhythmically. Otherwise it's a bit cheap." I saw lots of his pencil marks on the score such as: cantabile, silence, no pause here, just separate, clean pedal, more melodic voicing, remain soft, stay soft, quiet, hear tenor, clearer, articulate, in time, silvery soft, gentler, take time....Regarding teaching he said "I prefer payment in blocks. My students pay monthly or for four lessons at a time. For this month, it's ok to pay on a lesson-by-lesson basis because maybe you wanna see what it's like to have lessons. From next month onwards you can pay monthly. Students of all standards are welcome. I'm also an accompanist who accompanies instrumentalists, singers, dancers and other performers for exams, auditions and live performances. Some of my adult students started learning the trumpet when they were eighteen years old. Their fingers are less dextrous and slower than say a twelve year old kid. Start training your fingers when you're still very young so that you can get much faster fingers. It'll improve your finger speed, accuracy, strength and dexterity to a great extent." He asked me to get him some Ravel scores as I can get them on the cheap from a friend of mine.
